field_reports.description:
A massive fire erupted at a Petronas gas pipeline in Putra Heights, Puchong, on April 1, injuring 145 individuals, including three children. The blaze, triggered by a gas leak, engulfed 500 meters and caused tremors in the area, damaging multiple homes and vehicles. Emergency responders successfully extinguished the fire by 3:45 PM, nearly eight hours after it began. As a precaution, 305 residents were evacuated and relocated to a temporary relief center at Masjid Putra Heights.

Medical teams mobilized swiftly, with 67 victims still hospitalized across Sultan Idris Shah Hospital (28), Cyberjaya Hospital (22), Putrajaya Hospital (13), and Ampang Hospital (2). Another 41 individuals have been discharged, while 37 sought private medical treatment. Most victims sustained second-degree burns but are in stable condition. Many also suffered from breathing difficulties and other injuries due to the intensity of the flames and resulting structural damage.

The disaster left significant destruction, with 190 houses and 159 vehicles—148 cars and 11 motorcycles—suffering various degrees of damage. Overhaul and cooling operations are ongoing to prevent potential reignition, while authorities continue assessing the full impact and coordinating relief efforts for affected communities. Attached herewith is a MRC situation Report MRC NEOC Sitrep #1.pdf
field_reports.summary: MYS: Fire - 04-2025 - Malaysia Gas pipeline fire

field_reports.description:
In Sabah, current flood situation the district of Pitas, Tenom, Beaufort, Membakut, Keningau, Sook, Kemabong , all evacuees has return to their home and all the PPS in the district has been closed since 16 March 2025, however 3 new district has been hit by flood where a total of 250 victims from 69 families have been evacuated, with six temporary relief centers (PPS) established across Beluran, Paitan, and Sandakan since today March 20, 2025.

Meanwhile, Beaufort, Tenom, and Keningau, which previously facing water shortage during the flood still facing the issues and the water supply disruptions remain a major challenge. In Tenom, 80% of the population (24,000 residents) continue to experience water shortages due to a damaged main pipeline. Meanwhile, in Keningau, two clogged water treatment plants are operating at only 50% capacity, impacting 45,000 residents. Efforts are ongoing by the government to address these issues and restore access to clean water.

The flood situation in Sarawak and Kuala Lumpur has been relatively mild compared to other states. Sarawak has reported 148 victims from 38 families, with three PPS operating across three districts since January 29, 2025. In Kuala Lumpur, the impact has been minimal, with seven victims and one PPS set up in a single district since March 1, 2025.

Meanwhile, Johor remains the most severely affected state, facing the most critical conditions and requiring extensive relief efforts due to the high number of displaced individuals and worsening weather conditions.

According to the latest report from the Department of Social Welfare, Johor remains the most severely affected state, with 3,515 victims and 1,040 displaced families across five districts. Since March 19, 2025, a total of 50 temporary relief centers (PPS) have been established to provide shelter and assistance to those impacted.

The METMalaysia forecast on March 20, 2025, indicates that Johor will experience the most significant impact, with continuous heavy rainfall expected in Kluang, Mersing, Pontian, Kulai, Kota Tinggi, and Johor Bahru until March 21, 2025. The prolonged rainfall poses an increased risk of flooding and landslides in these areas. Additionally, Tangkak, Segamat, Muar, and Batu Pahat remain on high alert due to persistent rain.

Meanwhile, in Sabah, as of March 20, 2025, moderate rain warnings have been issued for Ranau, Kota Belud, Telupid, Kinabatangan, Beluran, Sandakan, and Kudat, raising concerns over localized flooding. Residents in these areas are advised to stay alert and follow official updates for safety precautions.

field_reports.description:
As of 8:00 PM on 10 March 2025, the flood situation in Sabah has worsened, with 4,555 individuals from 1,493 families seeking refuge in relief centres. The affected districts include Tenom, Beaufort, Membakut, and Sook.

In Tenom, eight relief centres are sheltering 1,162 people from 435 families, while Beaufort has four operational centres housing 1,719 individuals from 556 families. Membakut's two centres are accommodating 896 people from 302 families, and Sook’s two centres are providing refuge for 778 evacuees from 200 families.

A total of 37 villages across these districts have been impacted, including 10 villages each in Beaufort, Membakut, and Tenom, five in Sook, and two in Keningau. Infrastructure has been severely affected, with heavy rainfall leading to road closures in Beaufort, Tenom, and Keningau. Notably, the Keningau-Kimanis road remains closed due to two landslides.

In response to the escalating situation, Prime Minister Datuk Seri Anwar Ibrahim has directed the National Disaster Management Agency (NADMA) to strengthen coordination between federal and state agencies to ensure that effective assistance reaches those affected.

The situation remains fluid, with authorities closely monitoring weather conditions and providing essential aid to the affected communities.

field_reports.description:
The severe flooding in Sabah, which began on March 8, 2025, rapidly escalated due to continuous heavy rainfall, affecting six districts: Beaufort, Membakut, Keningau, Sook, Tenom, and Kemabong. The situation worsened when the Tenom Dam was opened, causing further inundation downstream. By March 9, 4,555 individuals from 1,493 families were displaced, prompting the activation of 31 evacuation centers (PPS). Floodwaters severely disrupted daily life, damaging infrastructure, closing roads, and triggering landslides, particularly along the Kota Kinabalu-Tenom route. While floodwaters in Keningau began receding by March 11, some villages remained inundated, leaving essential services disrupted. By March 16, all PPS were officially closed, allowing displaced communities to return home. However, humanitarian needs persist, especially concerning water supply, health risks, and livelihood recovery.

Following the disaster, the Malaysian Red Crescent (MRC) deployed an assessment team consisting of four personnel, supported by two from MRC NHQ, to evaluate urgent humanitarian needs in the most critical areas: Keningau, Tenom, and Beaufort. The assessment identified significant health and water supply challenges across the affected districts. In Beaufort, two cases of Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease (HFMD) were reported at DUN Banir and SMK Beaufort 3 PPS, while stagnant floodwaters heightened the risk of a dengue outbreak. Water shortages severely impacted Mukim 6, N34 Lumadan, where 998 people from 486 households struggled to access clean water. Similarly, in Tenom, 80% of the population faced water shortages due to landslide damage to the main pipeline, affecting 24,000 residents. Despite water trucking operations using eight trucks, repairs at the Senagang Water Treatment Plant left 6,153 meter users without piped water. In Keningau, five HFMD cases were reported, and two clogged water treatment plants operated at only 50% capacity, affecting an estimated 45,000 people. In response to a request from PKOB Keningau District on March 13, MRC coordinated with the Sabah State Water Department to assist in water supply restoration efforts.

Additionally, hygiene promotion efforts have primarily been conducted by government agencies at PPS in Tenom but there has been minimal intervention in affected villages. Community leaders, such as UPPM N3 Lumadan’s Dioslin Alin @Agustine, emphasized the need for expanded hygiene awareness at the community level. Sanitation issues remains in affected areas, exacerbated by water shortages, have led to inadequate maintenance of latrines, increasing the risk of waterborne diseases such as diarrhea and skin infections. Similarly, limited access to handwashing facilities has resulted in unsafe hygiene practices. The floods also disrupted education, impacting 18 schools in Beaufort and six in Membakut. While schools in Membakut have resumed operations, some in Beaufort are still undergoing restoration. Many students, especially in Mukim 6 and Kampung Bakalau, lost essential school supplies, with more than 1,000 students affected. In Tenom, several schools, including SK Pekan, SK Giat Mara Tenom, SMK Entabuan, and SM St. Anthony, are expected to reopen on March 18.

The disaster also had a severe impact on livelihoods. In Mukim 6, where most residents rely on agriculture and fisheries, 40% of affected families are farmers, including palm oil workers, rubber tappers, and paddy farmers, who earn RM 200–500 per month. The floods destroyed crops and plantations, causing prolonged income loss, particularly for rubber tappers due to damaged trees. Fishermen, who constitute 60% of those affected, suffered significant equipment losses, limiting their ability to work. In Kampung Bakalau, an urban area, 70–80% of residents are small business owners and traders, while 20% are laborers. Many businesses sustained financial losses due to damaged goods and reduced consumer demand, making economic recovery difficult. Humanitarian aid has been ongoing, with organizations like Petronas donating 1,000 cartons of mineral water daily (5 days as recorded) to Tenom and PKOB Tenom contributing 1,800 additional cartons. MRC has provided food packs to affected communities and assisted government agencies in first aid, shelter setup, and evacuee registration. Despite floodwaters receding, urgent needs remain, particularly in restoring clean water access, strengthening health and hygiene promotion, supporting education, and rebuilding livelihoods.

field_reports.description:
Severe monsoon floods continue to devastate Sabah and Sarawak, displacing thousands and causing widespread disruption. Since 28 January 2025, continuous heavy rainfall, compounded by high tides and the Northeast Monsoon, has led to rising water levels, road inundations, and landslides. In Sarawak, the situation worsened due to the collision of extreme monsoon rains with high tides, triggering large-scale evacuations and the activation of multiple relief centers.

As of 31 January 2025, 12,486 evacuees from 3,648 families have been relocated to 62 temporary relief centers (PPS) in Sarawak. Bintulu remains the most severely impacted district, sheltering 5,885 evacuees from 1,649 families, followed by Serian (2,307 evacuees, 709 families) and Samarahan (2,005 evacuees, 670 families). Other significantly affected districts include Sibu (1,163 evacuees, 293 families), Miri (650 evacuees, 172 families), and Kuching (475 evacuees, 153 families), with a single evacuee recorded in Mukah. In Miri, continuous heavy rainfall triggered a major landslide, resulting in the tragic loss of five lives. 

In Sabah, while the flood situation remains relatively stable, the number of evacuees has slightly increased to 5,216 individuals from 1,820 families, compared to 5,195 evacuees the previous night. 33 PPS remain operational across nine affected districts, with Kota Marudu recording the highest number of displaced individuals (2,944 evacuees from 1,095 families), followed by Pitas (806 evacuees, 298 families) and Lahad Datu (514 evacuees, 136 families). Additional affected areas include Telupid, Paitan, Kota Belud, Beaufort, Beluran, and Tongod, where relief efforts are ongoing.

The State Disaster Management Committees in both Sarawak and Sabah are actively coordinating response efforts to ensure the safe relocation of affected communities and the continued operation of relief centers. Authorities report an increasing trend of evacuations in Pitas, while conditions in other districts remain stable. Humanitarian agencies and government response teams continue to work together, delivering food, medical aid, and essential supplies to displaced populations as flood response operations intensify. 

According to the latest weather forecast from MetMalaysia on 1 February 2025, a monsoon surge is expected between February 4 and 7, potentially bringing continuous heavy rainfall across Sabah and Sarawak. This could exacerbate the current flood situation, increasing the risk of further inundation and landslides. Authorities are on high alert and closely monitoring developments to implement necessary early action measures.
field_reports.summary: MYS: Flood - 01-2025 - East Malaysia Monsoon Flood

field_reports.description:
The flood situation in Malaysia has reached a critical level, with severe impacts across nine states. Over 140,000 people have been displaced due to heavy rainfall and rising river levels. Kelantan and Terengganu are the most affected, with evacuation centers established to house large numbers of evacuees. Government agencies and authorities are managing relief efforts, focusing on evacuation, temporary shelters, and assistance distribution.

Kelantan faces the most severe impacts, with 82,630 evacuees from 24,802 families across 10 districts. The Pasir Mas district is the worst hit, sheltering 24,890 people in 279 evacuation centers (PPS). In Terengganu, 31,182 evacuees from eight districts are housed in 332 PPS, with Besut being the hardest-hit district, accommodating 12,838 victims in 114 centers.

In other states, Kedah has 4,477 evacuees in 50 PPS across six districts, while Perlis and Selangor shelter 488 and 473 displaced individuals, respectively. Negeri Sembilan, Melaka, Johor, and Perak have smaller numbers of evacuees, but all are actively managing temporary shelters and relief efforts to support affected families. The situation remains dynamic, with ongoing rainfall forecasted to exacerbate the crisis in several regions.

contacts.title: IT/CEA

field_reports.description:
Dans la nuit du lundi 25 novembre 2024 des pluies diluviennes se sont abattues dans la commune de Mouila, de Port-Gentil, de Tchibanga et dans le Grand Libreville,  occasionnant des inondations dans les localités précitées. Ces inondations ont engendré des sinistrés (Mouila 120 ménages, 630 ménages dans le Grand Libreville, 80 ménages à Tchibanga et Port-Gentil 150 ménages sinistrés).

Les récentes pluies diluviennes qui se sont abattues dans ces villes, ont d’une part ravivé les inquiétudes quant à un risque imminent de submersion d’environ 15 000 ménages soit 75 000 personnes pour le cas de Port-Gentil, la capitale économique du Gabon ; car sur la presqu’île Mandji, la ville du sable semble de plus en plus menacée par la montée des eaux.

D’autre part, la menace de l’extension des zones inondables demeure une préoccupation majeure en ce qui concerne le Grand Libreville, Mouila et Tchibanga notamment à cause de leur proximité de nombreux cours d’eau (voir carte pour le Grand Libreville, les fleuves DOUROUGNI, NGOUNIÉ pour Mouila, la rivière MOUGOUTSI, fleuve NYANGA pour Tchibanga).

The Northeast Monsoon (MTL) began in early November 2024 and is expected to end by March 2025, during which Malaysia is forecasted to experience five to seven episodes of heavy rainfall. Continuous heavy rain lasting several days has resulted in flooding in low-lying and flood-prone areas, such as Kelantan, Terengganu, and several other regions in Peninsular Malaysia.

According to official statistics as of November 28, 2024, a total of 31,798 individuals from 9,613 families have been affected by the Northeast Monsoon floods in both the East and West Coasts. The affected states include Kelantan, Terengganu, Kedah, Perlis, Johor, and Perak. Official reports from the Social Welfare Department (JKM) indicate that 296 Temporary Evacuation Centers (PPS) have been established to accommodate those impacted. In Kelantan, electricity supply has been cut off in 17 areas across four districts due to worsening flood conditions. To date, only one fatality—a 33-year-old victim in Kelantan—has been reported, caused by electrocution.

Additionally, six major rivers in Kelantan have surpassed danger levels and are showing rising trends. These include Sungai Lanas in Jeli at 31.28 meters, Sungai Kelantan in Kuala Krai (25.41 meters), Sungai Kelantan in Machang (20.27 meters), Sungai Golok in Rantau Panjang (10.94 meters), Sungai Melor in Bachok (9.85 meters), and Sungai Semerak in Pasir Puteh (3.69 meters).

In Terengganu, the number of flood victims has risen sharply to 3,768 compared to 1,851 yesterday evening, with a total of 69 Temporary Evacuation Centers (PPS) opened across the districts of Besut, Setiu, Dungun, Hulu Terengganu, Marang, and Kemaman. Besut is the most affected district, recording 2,335 victims housed in 33 PPS, followed by Hulu Terengganu (513 people in 19 PPS), Setiu (388 people in 11 PPS), Dungun (246 people in two PPS), Kemaman (215 people in two PPS), and Marang (71 people in two PPS).

River levels at 11 stations in the state have also recorded readings exceeding the danger level, including Sungai Besut at Jambatan Keruak and Sungai Besut at Kampung La in Besut; Sungai Nerus at Kampung Langkap and Sungai Setiu at Kampung Besut in Setiu; Sungai Setiu at Jambatan Permaisuri; and Sungai Chalok at Jambatan Chalok in Setiu

METMalaysia also has release latest warning and weather alert as follow:
The Continuous Rainfall Warning (DANGER) is in effect until November 29, 2024, for the following areas:
i) Kelantan;
ii) Terengganu; and
iii) Pahang (Jerantut & Kuantan).

The Continuous Rainfall Warning (SEVERE) is in effect until November 29, 2024, for the following areas:
i) Perlis;
ii) Kedah (Kubang Pasu, Kota Setar, Pokok Sena, Padang Terap, Pendang, Sik & Baling);
iii) Perak (Hulu Perak); and
iv) Pahang (Cameron Highlands, Lipis, Maran, Pekan & Rompin).

The Continuous Rainfall Warning (ALERT) is in effect until November 29, 2024, for the following areas:
i) Kedah (Langkawi, Yan, Kuala Muda, Kulim & Bandar Baharu);
ii) Penang;
iii) Perak (Kerian, Larut, Matang and Selama, Kuala Kangsar, Kinta & Kampar);
iv) Pahang (Raub, Bentong, Temerloh & Bera);
v) Johor (Segamat, Mersing & Kota Tinggi); and
vi) Sabah: Sandakan (Telupid, Beluran & Sandakan) and Kudat

field_reports.description:
Kedah is currently the most severely affected state, with the number of flood victims rising from 2,882 individuals last night to 3,441 from 978 families this morning, an increase of 559 compared to earlier figures. The seven impacted districts are Pasu (704 people), Pendang (429 people), Kulim (86 people), Pokok Sena (773 people), Kuala Muda (131 people), Kota Setar (1,205 people), and Bandar Baharu (113 people), all of whom are currently housed in 28 temporary relief centers (PPS).

Datuk Zulkhairi Zainol Abidin, Director of the Kedah Social Welfare Department (JKM), assured that sufficient supplies of basic necessities and food are available for evacuees, and that conditions at the relief centers remain stable despite the growing number of displaced individuals.

On the other hand, the Public Infobanjir website by the Drainage and Irrigation Department (JPS) reported that the number of rivers at dangerous levels in Kedah has decreased from 10 yesterday to seven today. 

The rivers currently at risk are Sungai Padang Terap in Kepala Batas; Sungai Bata in Kampung Bata; Sungai Laka in Kampung Padang Pasir, Kubang Pasu; Sungai Anak Bukit in Taman Aman; Sungai Anak Bukit at Jambatan TAR, Kota Setar; Sungai Titi Kerbau in Kubur Panjang, Pendang; and Sungai Perik in Kampung Perik, Padang Terap.

In Penang, eight relief centers across three districts have been opened, providing shelter to 586 victims from 163 families. Seberang Perai Utara remains the most heavily impacted area with 411 victims, followed by Seberang Perai Tengah with 95, and Seberang Perai Selatan with 62.

In Sabah, floods that began on 16 September have affected 303 people from 79 families, all of whom have been relocated to a relief center in the Tongod district.

Similarly, Perlis has maintained four PPS locations, accommodating 149 victims in total, with 113 in Arau and 36 in Kangar.

In Sarawak, where the floods began earlier on 22 August, one PPS in Betong remains open, sheltering 105 victims from 26 families.

As of 19 September 2024, at 4:45 PM, a total of 5,024 people (1,428 families) from seven districts have been displaced and are currently residing in 46 temporary relief centers.

In Penang, eight relief centers across three districts have been opened, providing shelter to 586 victims from 163 families. Seberang Perai Utara remains the most heavily impacted area with 411 victims, followed by Seberang Perai Tengah with 95, and Seberang Perai Selatan with 62.

In Sabah, floods that began on 16 September have affected 303 people from 79 families, all of whom have been relocated to a relief center in the Tongod district.

Similarly, Perlis has maintained four PPS locations, accommodating 149 victims in total, with 113 in Arau and 36 in Kangar.

In Sarawak, where the floods began earlier on 22 August, one PPS in Betong remains open, sheltering 105 victims from 26 families.

As of 19 September 2024, at 4:45 PM, a total of 5,024 people (1,428 families) from seven districts have been displaced and are currently residing in 46 temporary relief centers.

field_reports.description: The flood situation in Penampang, Putatan, Tuaran, and Tamparuli has significantly improved, resulting in the closure of all four temporary evacuation centers (PPS) that have been operational since Sunday. According to the Sabah State Disaster Management Committee Secretariat, the Penampang Cultural Center PPS closed at 5 pm, while the Dewan Sri Putatan PPS ceased operations at 3 pm. Additionally, the other two PPS, namely Dewan Balai Raya Kampung Tutu Selupoh in Tuaran and Dewan Balai Raya Kampung Bantoi in Tamparuli, were closed at 2 pm. All evacuees have returned to their homes for cleaning.
field_reports.summary: MYS: Pluvial/Flash Flood - 07-2024 - Sabah flash flood #4 (2024-07-04)

field_reports.description:
Based on the statistics released by the Sabah State Disaster Management Committee (JPBN) Secretariat, the number of flood victims in Sabah as of 4 pm yesterday was 481 people from 147 families. This is an increase from 464 people from 140 families as of 8 am the same day, with the victims spread across four temporary evacuation centers (PPS) in the three affected districts of Penampang, Putatan, and Tuaran.

As of 8:30 am today 3/7/2024, a total of 503 people (148 families) are currently sheltered in 4 relief centres: 

1. Dewan Kebudayaan Penampang (296 people, 97 families)

2. SK Selupoh (33 people, 9 families)

3. Dewan Sri Putatan (156 people, 37 families)

4, Kg Bontoi Tamparuli (18 people, 5 families)

According to the National Disaster Management Agency (NADMA), flood preparedness in the affected districts is coordinated by the District Disaster Management Committee (JPBD). This includes the activation of PPS, the provision of operation rooms, and storage facilities. The JPBD is also collaborating with the Department of Social Welfare (JKM) to ensure that the needs of the victims at the evacuation centers are adequately met. At present, the situation in Sabah is managed well, with effective coordination among agencies overseen by the District Officer and the State Secretary according to NADMA.

 

The Malaysian Communications and Multimedia Commission (MCMC), in collaboration with telecommunications companies, successfully restored 14 out of 41 telecommunications towers in several areas of the West Coast of Sabah that were affected by floods as of 10 am on Tuesday. However, 27 towers are still not operational, and restoration efforts are ongoing.
field_reports.summary: MYS: Pluvial/Flash Flood - 07-2024 - sabah flash flood #3 (2024-07-03)

field_reports.description:
The number of flood victims relocated to Temporary Evacuation Centers (PPS) in Sabah increased to 464 as of 8 am this morning, compared to 450 victims at 4 am. This figure involves victims from four PPS to date, namely in Penampang, Putatan, Tuaran, and the small district of Tamparuli, according to Berita Harian.

The Secretariat of the State Disaster Management Committee (JPBN) reported that the increase involved victims relocated to the PPS at the Sabah Cultural Center Hall, Penampang, which rose to 279 victims from 261 this morning.

However, the number of flood victims at the PPS at Dewan Sri Putatan decreased to 138 at 8 am this morning, compared to 142 victims at 4 am. In Tuaran, the number of victims relocated to the PPS at Balai Raya Kampung Tutu Selupoh remained at 29 people from eight families since yesterday evening. The number of victims at the PPS at Balai Raya Kampung Bontoi, Tamparuli, also remained at 18 people from five families.

Several areas in the West Coast of Sabah, including the state capital, have been experiencing floods since Sunday evening due to heavy rain for more than five hours, causing several rivers to overflow. Putatan District has been declared a flood disaster area following continuous rain since 30/6/2024
field_reports.summary: MYS: Pluvial/Flash Flood - 07-2024 - Sabah Flash Flood #2 (2024-07-02)

field_reports.description: On June 30, 2024, heavy downpours led to severe flooding in Penampang, Sabah, affecting Kota Kinabalu, Tuaran, Inanam, and Menggatal. By July 1, the floods resulted in one fatality and displaced 114 people, with hundreds more calling for help. Penampang was the worst hit, with 23 villages affected. Rescue operations are ongoing with support from various agencies and volunteers. Extensive damage to homes, vehicles, crops, and infrastructure has been reported. Penampang MP Datuk Ewon Benedick provided RM 20,000 in financial aid to the Dewan Kebudayaan temporary relief centre. Emergency services are prioritizing the most affected areas. Continuous flooding poses further risks of casualties, property damage, and health issues. Prolonged recovery efforts are anticipated, with increased pressure on resources and services. The MRC sent a team to assess the situation in Penampang but has not yet been able to enter the area of the evacuation center due to impassable road access.

field_reports.description:
According to the latest report from METMalaysia, the transition phase of the monsoon began on March 29, 2024, and is projected to persist until May 2024. This phase brings about weak winds from varying directions across the country, creating conditions conducive to thunderstorms that often result in heavy rainfall and strong winds, particularly in the evening and early night hours. The areas most affected by these weather patterns include those along the west coast and interior of the peninsula, as well as parts of Sabah, Sarawak, and central Sarawak.

At present, the country is grappling with a heatwave, as reported by METMalaysia. Two states in Peninsular Malaysia, Temerloh in Pahang, and Gua Musang and Jeli in Kelantan, have recorded a level 2 heatwave, indicating particularly high temperatures. Additionally, Perlis, Johor, Terengganu, Sabah, Sarawak, Negeri Sembilan, Kedah, and Perak have experienced a level 1 heatwave. This intense heatwave has been a prominent feature of the weather in these regions, exacerbating the hot and dry conditions prevalent in many areas. However, with the onset of the monsoon transition phase, there is an expectation that these conditions will gradually alleviate, with a recovery anticipated by the middle of April.

As 4th April 2024, total of 58,080 families in 12 districts affected in Sabah due to drought and heat, while in other states are approximitedly around 20,000 thousand affected especially farmers in the Northern state and East Coast states

As of March 25, 2024, Malaysia is grappling with a severe heatwave and drought, particularly affecting regions such as Kedah, Perak, Perlis, and the Papar District in Sabah. The soaring temperatures coupled with minimal rainfall have raised significant concerns regarding public health and water scarcity. The Malaysian Ministry of Health (KKM) has reported 28 cases of heat-related illnesses, Kedah (8), Perak (7), Selangor (3), Negeri Sembilan (3), Sabah (3), Perlis (2), Johor (1), Pahang (1). While the Papar District in Sabah has been officially declared a drought disaster area, impacting around 150,000 residents.

In response to the crisis, WASH (Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene) teams have been deployed to assess available water sources and initiate relief efforts. However, operational challenges such as communication issues and inadequate storage infrastructure have impeded progress. Despite these obstacles, the WASH team in Papar has successfully produced 6,360 litres of potable water for distribution, providing much-needed relief to affected villages and institutions.

Meanwhile, an assessment team has been dispatched to Pulau Sebatik, Tawau, where a prolonged dry spell has led to water scarcity and inflated prices. To address this situation, the Malaysian Red Crescent Society (MRCS) National Headquarters is coordinating the deployment of water purification units to both Papar and Pulau Sebatik.

Furthermore, the National Disaster Management Agency (NADMA) has initiated Cloud Seeding Operations in Sabah, focusing on severely affected districts like Papar, Lahad Datu, and Tawau. This collaborative effort with relevant agencies and authorities aims to mitigate the impact of the drought and provide essential relief to affected communities. Additionally, the Sabah government allocated RM7.5 million to supply clean water to 58,080 families in 12 districts in the state that were affected by hot weather and drought.
field_reports.summary: MYS: Heat Wave - 03-2024 - Sabah and Peninsular Heat Wave #5 (2024-03-28)

field_reports.description:
The Malaysian Meteorological Department (MetMalaysia) has reported on the current heatwave situation across several regions in Malaysia. As of the latest update, Perlis, Hulu Perak, Perak, and Beaufort in Sabah have experienced a level two heatwave, characterized by daily maximum temperatures ranging from 37 to 40 degrees Celsius for at least three consecutive days.

Furthermore, a total of 29 areas in Peninsular Malaysia, three in Sarawak, and one in Sabah have been issued a level one heatwave alert. In Peninsular Malaysia, areas such as Kedah, Perak, Pahang, Johor, Kelantan, Melaka, and Negeri Sembilan are among those affected. The level one heatwave alert signifies daily maximum temperatures ranging from 35 to 37 degrees Celsius for at least three consecutive days.

MetMalaysia attributes these extreme weather conditions to the final phase of the Northeast Monsoon, which typically brings less cloud cover and rainfall to northern areas of the Peninsula, resulting in hotter and drier weather than usual. Additionally, the strong El Niño phenomenon currently affecting the world is expected to contribute to higher daily maximum temperatures across Malaysia.

The National Disaster Management Agency (Nadma) also has reported that a total of 27 cases of heat-related illnesses have been documented nationwide so far this year. Among these cases, one death attributed to heat stroke occurred in Pahang, although further details regarding the incident were not provided.

According to Nadma's briefing, one individual suffering from heat stroke and three others experiencing heat exhaustion are currently undergoing treatment in hospitals. Fortunately, the remaining cases have received treatment and have since recovered, as indicated by the Ministry of Health.

Of the reported cases, 22 involved adults while 5 involved teenagers. Kedah recorded the highest number of cases with 8, followed by Perak with 7, Selangor and Negeri Sembilan with 3 each, and Sabah, Perlis, Johor, and Pahang with 2, 2, 1, and 1 cases respectively.

Nadma also highlighted that two dams, the Sembrong Barat dam in Johor (33.6%) and the Air Itam dam in Penang (35.8%), are currently at critical levels.

Furthermore, in response to the final phase of the northeast monsoon, the fire and rescue department will be focusing on over 650 hotspots nationwide. Notably, Selangor, Johor, and Sarawak have reported the highest numbers of recurring fires in various environments such as bushes, plantations, forests, and waste disposal areas, according to Nadma's statement

Papar District in Sabah was declared a drought disaster. The declaration was made by Mohd Fuad Abdullah District Officer cum Chairman of the District Disaster Management Committee (JPBD). The declaration was made based on reports and information on the ground received from the agencies in JBPD, It is a comprehensive measure to assist the relevant agencies in the management of water distribution. The distribution of water supply which is made on a schedule also gets the assistance of water tankers from the Sabah State Water Department (JANS) Ranau District, Beaufort District Council, JBPN Kota Kinabalu, and the rest are rented from the private sector. Priority will be given to hospitals, houses of worship, homes for the elderly, and schools first, then to affected residential areas. It is estimated that approximately 154,600 of the population of Papar District in Sabah are potentially affected by the ongoing situation.

The hot weather and drought due to the El-Nino phenomenon that hit the country have had a serious impact on Sabah's agricultural sector, said Deputy Chief Minister, Datuk Dr Jeffrey Kitingan, the state's Minister of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food Industry. low rainfall rate since last January and February around 80 millimeters, has affected crops and land management for agriculture, causing agricultural yields to decrease. Hot weather and prolonged drought pose a major challenge to food production for food security in Sabah. "The lack of rain and the water level in the drainage is reduced by 10 to 40 percent, affecting agriculture, animal husbandry, aquaculture, and rubber production. Jeffrey said that there are several rivers in five districts in Sabah, namely Kota Belud, Keningau, Membakut, Tambunan, and Kota Marudu, facing a critical drop in water levels, including Sungai Padas in Beaufort at a level of 2.58 meters compared to the normal level of 4.5 meters, previously. Several measures have been taken to deal with the situation, including postponing certain agricultural activities and the use of types of crops that require less water or can survive during the dry season. Entrepreneurs are also advised not to keep stocks in large quantities, in addition to taking measures to reduce losses. Water rationing and the use of portable water pumps have also been mobilized to ensure sufficient water supply.

Meanwhile, on March 13, 2024, The Malaysian Meteorological Department (MetMalaysia) issued a hot weather alert level in eight areas in the north of Peninsular Malaysia. MetMalaysia informed that among the areas involved are Padang Terap, Kota Setar, Pokok Sena, Pendang, Sik, and Baling in Kedah; Hulu Perak in Perak and the state of Perlis. According to the statement, heat alert level is categorized when the daily maximum temperature of an area reaches 35 to 37 degrees Celsius for at least three consecutive days.

MRC NHQ has deployed 2 staff members to Sabah to facilitate and support the assessment conducted by the MRC Sabah Chapter. The MRC NHQ is also monitoring the current situation in other states in the peninsula that are placed on alert, including will deploy assessment teams to the states to obtain detailed information.
field_reports.summary: MYS: Heat Wave - 03-2024 - Sabah and Peninsular Heat Wave #3 (2024-03-14)

field_reports.description: MetMalaysia also informed that that the heat wave can lead to incidents of haze, drought, the reduction of water level in dams, heat stroke and forest fires. The department is advising Malaysians to drink enough water, reduce outdoor activities, wear comfortable clothing that is moisture wicking and refrain from open burning
field_reports.summary: MYS: Heat Wave - 03-2024 - Heat Wave Warning by METMalaysia #2 (2024-03-08)

field_reports.gov_affected_pop_centres: Langkawi Island, Kota Setar, Yan, Pendang, Pokok Sena, Sik, Baling in Kedah; Seberang Perai Utara in Penang and Kuala Kangsar, Perak, while the area affected in Sabah is Beaufort.
field_reports.description:
Nine areas in the peninsula and one in Sabah recorded alert-level hot weather as of 6 pm today, according to the Malaysian Meteorological Department (MetMalaysia).

In a statement posted on its Facebook page, MetMalaysia said the nine areas in the peninsula are Langkawi Island, Kota Setar, Yan, Pendang, Pokok Sena, Sik, Baling in Kedah; Seberang Perai Utara in Penang and Kuala Kangsar, Perak, while the area affected in Sabah is Beaufort.

The alert level refers to a daily maximum temperature of 35° to 37°Celsius for at least three consecutive days.

MetMalaysia had previously issued a statement, saying that the country was currently experiencing the final phase of the northeast monsoon, which is expected to last until the end of March.

The department said during the phase, cloud formation and rainfall distribution were generally lower in most places, especially in the northern areas of the peninsula, including Perak, as well as in Pahang and Kelantan.

The absence of rain for a long period could lead to hotter and drier weather than usual, it added.

Hot weather during this period is a recurring phenomenon that occurs annually from February to May. During this period, the daily maximum temperature may surpass 35°Celsius in the early afternoon.
field_reports.summary: MYS: Heat Wave - 02-2024 - MYS: Heat Wave 2024 # 1

field_reports.description: Between January 10 and 14, Penang is set for a planned water supply disruption affecting 590,000 registered users. This necessary interruption is crucial for replacing two 1200mm diameter valves and addressing leaks at the Sungai Dua Water Treatment Plant. Residents in areas like George Town, Pulau Tikus, Jelutong, Gelugor, Bukit Jambul, Relau, Bayan Lepas including the airport, Bayan Baru, Batu Maung, Teluk Kumbar, Teluk Tempoyak, Pulau Jerejak and Pulau Betong will experience disruptions in water supply during this period. The WASH team from the Malaysian Red Crescent Society (MRCS) is actively engaged in resolving this issue.Top of Form

In response to an unexpected water supply interruption affecting 2,670 families in Besut, Terengganu, the WASH team was activated to address the issue. The disturbance originated from incomplete repair work on a 600 mm pipe near the riverbank, complicated by the tide, making hole digging challenging. The affected areas include Bukit Keluang, Persiaran Limbongan, Taman Mawaddah, Kg Limbongan, Taman Koperat Putera, Peng Nyireh, Kg Air Tawar, Tanjung Demong, Taman Noryanti, Seberang Kastam, RAKR Peng Nyireh, and surrounding regions. The water supply disruptions are anticipated to persist from January 1 to January 21, 2024.

field_reports.description:
The total number of individuals affected by the floods in Johor has risen sharply to 4,868, representing 1,379 families who have sought refuge in 50 temporary evacuation centers (PPS).

Tan Sri Dr. Azmi Rohani, the State Secretary of Johor, highlighted a significant increase of 3,715 individuals from 1,078 families across the six impacted districts—Kota Tinggi, Kluang, Segamat, Johor Bahru, Kulai, and Pontian—compared to the previous count.

Kota Tinggi stands out as the most severely affected district, with 2,050 people from 543 families seeking shelter in 23 PPS.
In Kluang, 1,442 individuals from 445 families are affected, and they are distributed across 14 PPS.
Johor Bahru is currently accommodating 1,253 affected people from 359 families in 10 PPS.
Kulai reports 86 affected individuals from 23 families seeking refuge in 1 PPS.
Segamat has 20 affected individuals from 5 families housed in 1 PPS.
Pontian registers 17 affected individuals from 4 families seeking shelter in 1 PPS.

In response to an unexpected water supply interruption affecting 2,670 families in Besut, Terengganu, the WASH team was activated to address the issue. The disturbance originated from incomplete repair work on a 600 mm pipe near the riverbank, complicated by the tide, making hole digging challenging. The affected areas include Bukit Keluang, Persiaran Limbongan, Taman Mawaddah, Kg Limbongan, Taman Koperat Putera, Peng Nyireh, Kg Air Tawar, Tanjung Demong, Taman Noryanti, Seberang Kastam, RAKR Peng Nyireh, and surrounding regions. The water supply disruptions are anticipated to persist from January 1 to January 21, 2024.

field_reports.description:
As of the latest update, the number of individuals affected by the ongoing floods in Johor, Malaysia, has surged to 1,153, encompassing 301 families. This represents a significant increase from the initial figures reported. The affected individuals are distributed across various districts, with Kota Tinggi bearing the brunt with 761 individuals from 191 families. Mersing, Kluang, and Johor Bahru are also grappling with the impact, indicating a widespread crisis.
In response to the escalating situation, 12 temporary evacuation centers (PPS) have been established to provide shelter and support to those affected. The coordinated effort is evident in the strategic placement of these centers across the districts, emphasizing the collective commitment to ensuring the well-being of the affected families.
Compounding the challenges, the Malaysian Meteorological Department has issued a warning of continuous heavy rainfall in critical areas of Johor until Sunday, heightening the risk of further flooding. Other regions are also on alert for moderate rainfall, necessitating ongoing vigilance and preparedness.

In response to an unexpected water supply interruption affecting 2,670 families in Besut, Terengganu, the WASH team was activated to address the issue. The disturbance originated from incomplete repair work on a 600 mm pipe near the riverbank, complicated by the tide, making hole digging challenging. The affected areas include Bukit Keluang, Persiaran Limbongan, Taman Mawaddah, Kg Limbongan, Taman Koperat Putera, Peng Nyireh, Kg Air Tawar, Tanjung Demong, Taman Noryanti, Seberang Kastam, RAKR Peng Nyireh, and surrounding regions. The water supply disruptions are anticipated to persist from January 1 to January 21, 2024.
field_reports.summary: MYS: Flood - 01-2024 - Water Disruption in Besut, Terengganu #7 (2024-01-05)

field_reports.description:
The number of flood victims in three states has further decreased to 1,762 individuals in 17 temporary relocation centers (PPS) as of 8 p.m., while Terengganu has fully recovered from the disaster. According to the latest report on nationwide disaster incidents issued by the National Disaster Control Center of the National Disaster Management Agency (NADMA), the number of flood victims in Kelantan continues to decline to 1587 individuals in 12 PPS, compared to 6,684 individuals in 24 PPS earlier today.

According to the report, PPS in Kelantan includes two in Pasir Mas accommodating 365 individuals, eight in Tumpat (1,191 individuals), and two in Kuala Krai (31 individuals). In Pahang, the number of flood victims remains at 34 individuals, taking shelter in two PPS in the Maran District, while 87 victims of a landslide incident in Cameron Highlands remain in a PPS opened in that area.

The number of flood victims in Johor has also remained unchanged, with 54 individuals still placed in two PPS in the Segamat District this evening. A total of 53 schools in eight districts in the state have been affected by the three waves of floods that hit Terengganu since November 20, with 79 schools being used as temporary relocation centers (PPS) to accommodate flood victims in all districts. The estimated total losses faced by schools due to the recent three waves of floods in Terengganu amount to RM340,000, involving damage to furniture and equipment.

field_reports.description:
The flood situation in Kelantan has deteriorated further, with the number of flood beneficiaries increasing to 12,572 people from 3,860 families as of 8 a.m. today. This is compared to 9,721 people from 2,962 families recorded last night. According to the State Disaster Management Secretariat (JPBN), Kelantan, Machang, and Kota Bharu are the latest areas affected by floods. Currently, all the beneficiaries are taking shelter in 82 Temporary Relocation Centres (PPS) spread across seven districts, including Pasir Mas, Jeli, Tanah Merah, Gua Musang, and Kuala Krai.

In Machang, six PPS are accommodating 462 beneficiaries from 167 families, while Kota Bharu has one PPS providing shelter to 25 beneficiaries from 7 families. In Pasir Mas, 24 PPS are operating with 7,210 beneficiaries from 2,334 families; Tanah Merah has 19 PPS with 1,783 beneficiaries from 546 families; Jeli has two PPS with 255 beneficiaries from 75 families; Gua Musang has five PPS with 271 families; and Kuala Krai has 25 PPS with 2,566 beneficiaries from 670 families.

In Terengganu, the flood situation is worsening, with the number of beneficiaries relocated to PPS in seven districts increasing to 8,808 people from 2,402 families as of 8 a.m. today. This is compared to 5,170 people from 1,382 families recorded last night. According to the State Disaster Management Committee Secretariat in Terengganu (JPBNT), Hulu Terengganu is the most affected, with 3,005 beneficiaries from 874 families placed in 34 PPS. Dungun follows with 1,725 beneficiaries from 444 families in 30 PPS.

In Kemaman, 964 beneficiaries from 290 families are placed in 10 PPS, Besut has 1,609 beneficiaries from 364 families in 24 PPS, Setiu has 1,432 beneficiaries from 410 families in 30 PPS, and Marang has 48 beneficiaries from 12 families still in two PPS. The third wave of floods in the state have most recently affected Kuala Nerus, where 25 beneficiaries from eight families relocated to three PPS last night.

Flooding in Dungun, Kemaman, Marang, and Setiu affected and displaced 2340 people. Today, four states, namely Kelantan, Terengganu, Perak, and Selangor, were affected by the flood wave, with more than 6,000 victims being moved to 29 temporary evacuation centers (PPS).

The number of flood victims in Kelantan has increased to 4,530 people from 1,462 families as of 8 a.m. today, compared to 4,398 people from 1,405 families last night.

According to the Disaster Information Portal of the Department of Social Welfare (JKM), all victims are currently taking shelter in 12 temporary relocation centers (PPS) in the Pasir Mas and Tanah Merah districts.

In Pasir Mas, 11 PPS are open, including Gual To'Deh National School, Rantau Panjang, which accommodates 813 victims from 264 families, Gual Tinggi National School (898 victims from 293 families), Baroh Pial Secondary National School (634 victims from 225 families), Lati National Religious Secondary School (88 victims from 23 families), and Padang Licin Mosque (116 victims from 45 families).

Six more PPS are located at Gual Periok National School, accommodating 269 victims from 79 families, Sri Kiambang National School (345 victims from 107 families), Chicha Tinggi National School (261 victims from 72 families), Lati National School (223 victims from 62 families), Gual Periok Secondary National School (153 victims from 41 families), and Sri Rantau Panjang 2 National School (711 victims from 243 families).

Additionally, a PPS is open in the Tanah Merah district, namely Padang Kijang Hall, with 19 victims from eight families.

Meanwhile, based on the report from https://publicinfobanjir.water.gov.my/, the Golok River in Pasir Mas recorded a dangerous water level of 9.97 meters, while the Golok River in Kuala Jambu, Tumpat is at a cautionary level with a reading of 2.30 meters.

The floods in Terengganu and Kelantan are getting worse as the rain in both states continues and causes the number of displaced people to increase. In Terengganu, 18 temporary evacuation centers (PPS) were opened in five districts: nine in Kuala Nerus, four in Kuala Terengganu, two each in Setiu and Marang, and one in Besut. Also affected, 13 schools had to be closed.

field_reports.summary: MYS: Flood - 11-2023 - East Coast Monsoon Flood 2023/24

results.name: MYS: Flood - 11-2023 - East Coast Monsoon Flood 2023/24

field_reports.description:
Heavy rain resulted in floods in some Malaysian states, with nearly 1,000 people moved to evacuation centers on Monday. Deputy Prime Minister Zahid Hamidi said as of noon on Monday, six districts in Selangor, Perak, and Pahang were affected by floods, with 881 victims from 237 families evacuated to 12 temporary flood relief centers.

No deaths have been recorded so far, said the National Disaster Management Agency. Malaysia’s weather agency also issued an adverse weather warning for three days until Wednesday. It said that thunderstorms with heavy rains and strong winds are forecast to hit most areas in the western region of the peninsula, northern Sarawak, and the western part of Sabah in the late afternoon until evening.

Over in Selangor, four districts – Gombak, Hulu Selangor, Hulu Langat, and Sepang – were affected by floods. The authorities said that as of 4 pm on Monday, 569 victims from 150 families were currently housed in eight relief centers. Over in Perak, as of noon on Monday, the number of flood victims had fallen to 219 people from 63 families. This is compared with the 272 people from 75 families on Saturday night. Meanwhile, in Pahang, 87 people from 17 families were housed in one relief center.

field_reports.description:
The current situation of dengue fever in Malaysia epidemiology week 42 (October 15 – October 21, 2023).

In the 42nd Epidemiological Week of 2023, the number of dengue fever cases reported was 2,262 cases compared to 2,271 cases in the week previously, which is a decrease of nine (9) cases (0.4%). There are six (6) deaths due to dengue fever complications were reported on Sunday 42nd Epidemiology of 2023.

Cumulative cases of dengue fever reported until Sunday the 42nd epidemiology was as many as 96,443 cases compared to 48,109 cases for the same period in 2022, which is an increase of 48,334 (100.5%). A total of 73 deaths due to dengue fever complications have been reported compared to 29 deaths for the same period in 2022.

The number of hotspot localities reported during the 42nd Epidemiological Week decreased by six (6) localities with a total of 73 localities compared to 79 hotspot localities in the previous week. Of the 73 reported localities, 51 localities in the State of Selangor, nine (9) localities in WPKL & Putrajaya, five (5) localities in Negeri Perak, three (3) localities in Negeri Sembilan, two (2) localities in Negeri Sarawak and one (1) locality each in the State of Kedah, Penang, and Sabah. 

Link to the Malaysian Ministry of Health's media statement regarding the dengue situation in Malaysia dated 28 Oct 2023

field_reports.epi_notes_since_last_fr: The states of Perak and Kelantan experienced an increase in dengue cases reported yesterday
field_reports.description:
Uncertain weather conditions are among the contributing factors to the increase in dengue fever cases in Kelantan. State Health Department (JKNK) director Datuk Dr. Zaini Hussin said this was due to the hot weather and heavy rain that occurred recently, which provided favorable conditions for the breeding of Aedes mosquitoes. Dengue fever is still endemic in Kelantan with cases reported throughout the year and until September with a cumulative total of more than 1,500 cases.  For Tumpat district, 220 cases have been reported up to September 30 this year compared with only 38 cases recorded in the same period last year, which is an increase of 479 percent.

meanwhile, in Perak, the cumulative number of dengue fever cases increased to 2,762 cases from January to September this year, compared to 851 cases in the same period last year. State Human Resources, Health, Indian Community Affairs, and National Integration Committee chairman A. Sivanesan said this was an increase of 1,911 cases or 224.6 percent.
He said one death was recorded in Kuala Kangsar during this period while there were no fatalities during the same period last year. “A total of 75 dengue fever cases were recorded in the 39th epidemiological week (ME) this year compared to only 24 cases last year. Among the areas with the most number of dengue fever cases recorded are Kampung Tersusun Batu 5 in the Kinta district with 23 cases while Block A (Zone 1) of the Royal Malaysian Navy Base in Manjung district had 10 cases.

field_reports.description:
The Air Pollution Index (API) readings in 15 locations across the country continue to be unhealthy as of 8 a.m. today. A check on the Department of Environment's (DoE) Air Pollutant Index Management System (APIMS) website shows that Cheras has the highest reading of 164, followed closely by Nilai at 163. Cheras reached a reading of 160 as early as 1 a.m., and the maximum reading of 165 was recorded at 7 a.m. today. Nilai, on the contrary, has recorded a reading of 163 since 6 a.m. Other areas in the unhealthy category are Petaling Jaya, Shah Alam, and Seremban, all at 158, Putrajaya and Banting (157), and Port Dickson (156). They are followed by Batu Muda (154), Klang, Johan Setia, and Bukit Rambai (153), Alor Gajah (136), Taiping (129), and Tangkak (107).

 

APIMS measures the API readings between 0 and 50 as good, 51 and 100 as moderate, 101 to 200 as unhealthy, 201 to 300 as very unhealthy and any readings of 300 and above are declared as hazardous. Malaysia is suffering from the haze due to the re-emergence of transboundary haze pollution from Indonesia. Department of Environment director-general Wan Abdul Latiff Wan Jaffar in a statement on Friday, attributed the latest smog to hundreds of forest fires in Indonesia. He added the fires were worsening air pollution on the country's west coast and in Sarawak on the Malaysian part of Borneo Island. "Overall air quality in the country shows deterioration. Forest fires that occur in the southern part of Sumatra and the central and southern parts of Kalimantan (Borneo), Indonesia have caused a haze to cross borders," he said. He also said satellite imagery showed 52 forest fire "hotspots" in Sumatra and 264 in Borneo, according to a report from the Singapore-based Asean Specialized Meteorological Centre (ASMC), which tracks haze affecting Southeast Asia.

field_reports.description:
The Head of the Disaster Management Secretariat, Kedah Civil Defense Force (APM), Major (PA) Muhammad Suhaimi Mohd Zain reported that 1,696 victims from 494 families were placed in 12 Temporary Transfer Centers (PPS) in four districts.

In Baling district, a total of 305 from 73 families were placed in Surau An-Nur, and 103 victims from 40 families were placed at the Sekolah Kebangsaan (SK) Kampung Iboi. 139 victims from 44 families were placed in PPS at Sekolah Menengah Kebangsaan (SMK) Jerai while PPS SK Kampung Keda housed a total of 144 victims from 40 families.

In Pokok Sena, a total of 249 victims from 68 families were accommodated in SK Bukit Hijau while PPS Maahad Tarbiyah Derang accommodated a total of 148 victims from 40 families and SK Permatang Limau accommodated a total of 15 victims from four families.

 

In the Kota Setar district, PPS SK Taman Aman houses a total of 267 victims from 95 families while Kepala Batas National Secondary School (SMK) houses a total of 41 victims from 16 families. The PPS at SMK Changlun houses a total of 83 victims from 23 families while the PPS SK Malau houses a total of 143 victims from 33 families. The PPS at the Lubuk Batu PPK Hall housed 59 victims from 22 families.

field_reports.description:
Dengue cases have risen by almost 19% in early September compared to late August, says the Health Ministry. The health director-general Datuk Dr Muhammad Radzi Abu Hassan said 2,284 dengue cases were recorded from 3 Sept to 9 Sept 2023.

This marked an increase of 360 cases, or 18.7%, compared to 1,924 dengue cases recorded from Aug 27 to Sept 2. Dr Muhammad Radzi said two deaths related to dengue complications were also recorded from Sept 3 to Sept 9. “Cumulatively, Malaysia recorded a 110.5% increase in the number of dengue cases as of Sept 9, 2023, with 82,485 cases. “The same period in 2022 saw 39,188 dengue cases recorded,” he said in a statement yesterday.
“Fifty-nine dengue related deaths were recorded cumulatively as of Sept 9, 2023, compared to 24 deaths during the same period last year,” he added. Dr Muhammad Radzi said there were currently 66 dengue hotspot localities nationwide as of Sept 9.

“Of the 66, Selangor had the highest number of dengue hotspots (47), followed by Kuala Lumpur and Putrajaya (13) and Kelantan (3), while Penang, Perak and Sabah had one each,” he said.

According to Deputy Health Minister Datuk Lukanisman Awang Sauni in one of the official statement during the press conference in 2023, from July 2023 to date (November 2023), there have been nine cases of monkeypox reported in Malaysia where the first and second cases were reported in Kuala Lumpur in July 2023. The third and fourth cases were reported in October, and follow with five more cases in November the same year. The fifth was detected in Sarawak while the sixth, seventh, eighth, and ninth case occurred in Kuala Lumpur. 

As for 20th August 2024, there are no Monkey Pox cases has been recorded by Malaysian Ministry of Health and the only recorded cases are the previous 9 cases in 2023 which fully recovered with no fatality
field_reports.description: Currently based on the 2023 and latest report from Ministry of Health, there is no primary or secondary effects on the health system and population since the Ministry is closely monitoring all the situation and disseminating information on the Monkey Pox and especially for travelers going abroad or coming back from risk country.

The Malaysian Meteorological Department (MetMalaysia) predicts heavy rain and strong winds in the northern states of the peninsula and western Sabah as well as its waters on Wednesday until next May 31. MetMalaysia in a statement in their infosite informed that, based on analysis of weather models, it found that westerly winds in the country's region are expected to increase due to Typhoon Mawar

Additional information by Met Malaysia,  strong winds and rough seas are also expected to occur in the waters of the South China Sea, Phuket and North Malacca Straits starting from May 26 to June 1 2023

field_reports.description:
The Meteorological Department (MetMalaysia) has issued a level one hot weather status for four areas in the peninsula and one in Sarawak. According to the latest hot weather data uploaded on the department’s Facebook today, the four areas in Peninsula Malaysia involved Baling in Kedah as well as Hulu Perak, Kinta, and Manjung in Perak. Meanwhile, the level one area in Sarawak is Mukah. “No areas in Sabah are at level one,” The alert level is when the maximum daily temperature is between 35 to 37 degrees Celsius for at least three days consecutively.

on April 27 last An 18-month-old girl in Kelantan was reported to have died on Tuesday, believed to be due to heat stroke, the second victim due to the hot weather in the state. According to a Berita Harian report, the child's father, Ahmad Faris Fazli Mohd Nasir said, he took his only child Nur Imani to the Emergency Unit of Raja Perempuan Zainab II Hospital last Monday after his son vomited. According to him, the autopsy report conducted at the hospital found that the cause of Nur Imani's death was due to heat stroke. Previously on April 25, an 11-year-old boy from Kampung Perupok in Bachok, Kelantan was reported to be the first victim of heat stroke when he reportedly died. The victim, Muhamad Syamil Aqil, is said to have died at 9.27 am while receiving treatment at a clinic.

 

Also on May 5, Utusan Malaysia reported that schools across the country had been told to stop all outdoor activities, including cross-country running, amid the heat wave. Education Minister Fadhlina Sidek said the ministry sent a circular informing all principals and school administrations about this decision.

Deputy Prime Minister Datuk Seri Dr Ahmad Zahid Hamidi said the secretariat of the National Disaster Management Committee has met and carried out coordination efforts with various relevant ministries and departments to help the people cope with this new phenomenon.

 

MRCS NHQ has coordinated with the MRCS of the states involved for the purpose of monitoring the effects of heat waves and identifying the appropriate form and type of response that will be channeled. At the same time, MRCS is arranging coordination with relevant government agencies at the national and state levels for appropriate response purposes.

field_reports.description:
According to media reports (Utusan Malaysia) the current hot and dry weather has destroyed 7,800 acres of rice planted in Kelantan. The extremely hot weather not only stunted the plants but also affected the water sources. This will cause a loss of income and have an impact on food security in the state.

Local authorities through Kemubu Agricultural Development Authority (Kada) have handed over an additional 16 water pumps with a capacity of three to 20 cubic feet a second, to alleviate the situation. Kada will also supply farmers who are registered with the agency with the diesel fuel needed to run the water pumps.

 

In the meantime, MRCS is monitoring the situation and if the situation worsens MRCS will conduct a rapid assessment to see the appropriate response to help those affected especially in the livelihood sector.

field_reports.description:
More than 200 victims were reportedly affected as 105 houses collapsed due to the waves during the high tide phenomenon that occurred in Kampung Forest and Kampung Tinusa Dua on 23/12/2022. 

According to Malaysian Fire and Rescue Department Operations Center(JBPM PGO), the tidal wave phenomenon happened around 10pm and all the victims were evacuated in the temporary evacuation center of Sungai Anib Dua National School (SMK). Estimated around 100 houses collapsed in Kampung Forest while 500 other houses were threatened in the same incident. In addition, five more houses also collapsed in Kampung Tinusa Dua and another 20 were reported to be threatened.

field_reports.description:
More than 27,000 people have been evacuated in the Malaysian states of Johor, Pahang, Negeri Sembilan and Melaka when their homes were hit by floods due to heavy rain brought by the northeast monsoon, when continuous heavy rain began on 28 February 2023. Johor is the worst-hit state with more than 25,000 people in relief centres on Thursday morning (Mar 2), compared with 9,162 on Wednesday night. 

There has been ongoing flooding from the same monsoon season which started in December 2022, but the current flooding is above average as it has never been experienced in March. Earlier in February, there has been minor floods in Johor which was expected in terms of timing and scale, and the current scale of flooding is extraordinary.

According to the Ministry of Natural Resources, Environment And Climate Change, the Segamat district recorded 627 mm of rain from 28 to late 01 March. More than 200 mm of rain was recorded in 29 locations of Johor state in 19 hours on 01 March. Rivers were above the danger mark in at least 16 locations by late (local time) 01 March, including the Skudai River at Kampung Laut in Johor Bahru, which jumped to 5.49 metres on 01 March, well above the danger mark of 3 metres. Heavy rain was reported in other parts of Peninsular Malaysia, in particular in Pahang where 72mm of rain fell in 1 hour and 431 mm in 19 hours in Pukin in the Rompin district.

Some roads were closed due to rising water levels, including one that was affected due to landslides. Continuous rain at a “dangerous” level is expected in Johor and three other states – Melaka, Negeri Sembilan and Pahang – until Thursday.

The Segamat district is the worst affected in Johor with 2,189 evacuated into 60 centres, followed by Kluang with 1,571 families in 39 centres. According to local authorities, the Chaah subdistrict in Segamat is said to have experienced the worst flood in 20 years, where most structures (except for the police station) in the Chaah town are now underwater. People were evacuated in distress as they stood on their roofs, and evacuation has been slow as the fast currents render some boats unsuitable for search and rescue.

According to Malaysian Meteorological Dept based on the department weather model analysist and information shared during MTL Coordination with all agencies, monsoon rain and strong winds are expected to continue until 30th January 2023. Heavy rains and strong wind also expected to occur in the interior and East Coast of Peninsular Malaysia and several warnings of heavy rains had been released by MetMalaysia for Johor, Sabah and Pahang starting for the period of 5 days starting on 26 to 30 January 2023.

Current flood situation and statistics nationwide as update by NADMA and affected states's JPBN are as below:

  1. Johor - 1,486 families (5,394 people) with 56 relief centres operating
  2. Sabah - 347 families (959 people) with 9 relief centres operating
  3. Pahang - 84 families (286 people) with 4 relief centres operating
  4. Sarawak - 17 families (56 people) with 2 relief centres operating

Total families affected throughout 4 states - 1,934 families (6,695 people) with 71 relief centres still open.

Between 25-27 November 2022, two to four boats reportedly set off from Bangladesh. We assume that they were headed to either Malaysia or Indonesia as has been the case in the past. News reports on 9 December indicate that one boat was rescued by a Vietnamese vessel and handed over to the Myanmar authorities. One boat with 160 passengers is reportedly stranded in the Andaman Sea. It is alleged that the boat is located within the Malaysian Search and Rescue (SAR) region. The last known location of this boat on 9 December via a satellite phone on the boat was approximately 388 km from Ranong, Thailand, 352 km from Port Blair, India, and 619 km from Langkawi, Malaysia. The boat has reportedly broken down and they have been without food or water for an untold number of days. The location and condition of the two other boats are yet unknown
field_reports.summary: MYS: Population Movement - 2022-12 - Andaman Sea boat arrivals

field_reports.description:
In the early morning of Friday 16 December 2022 at 2.30 am, a large landslide occured in  at a camping site in Batang kali, Selangor. According to the Director of the Malaysian Fire and Rescue Department (JBPM) Selangor, Datuk Norazam Khamis, JBPM received an emergency call at 2.24am before moving their personnel and assets to the scene of the incident. About 69 people are feared trapped and buried in a landslide that occurred and based on PDRM preliminary information, there were 100 people at the campsite who may have fallen victim to the landslide.

The Search and Rescue Operation (SAR) has involved various agencies such as Malaysian Fire and Rescue special team STORM, SMART team, Malaysian Civil Defence (APM), Malaysian Military Force (ATM) and Ministry of Health and other agencies.

SAR Operation were halt at 10pm due to the rain by Head of Operation from Fire and Rescue Department and continued the next day 17th December at 8am.

Latest update 19/12/2022, entering the fourth day, the search and rescue (SAR) operation for nine remaining victims missing in the landslide tragedy at the Fathers' Organic Farm campsite, Gohtong Jaya, Batang Kali here continues today. Director of the Fire and Rescue Department and Selangor Datuk Norazam Khamis when contacted by Bernama said his side will focus on Sector A (Hillview) and Sector C (Riverside) as well as the surrounding areas that have not been excavated.

In the early morning of Friday 16 December 2022 at 2.30 am, a large landslide occured in  at a camping site in Batang kali, Selangor. According to the Director of the Malaysian Fire and Rescue Department (JBPM) Selangor, Datuk Norazam Khamis, JBPM received an emergency call at 2.24am before moving their personnel and assets to the scene of the incident. About 69 people are feared trapped and buried in a landslide that occurred and based on PDRM preliminary information, there were 100 people at the campsite who may have fallen victim to the landslide.

The Search and Rescue Operation (SAR) has involved various agencies such as Malaysian Fire and Rescue special team STORM, SMART team, Malaysian Civil Defence (APM), Malaysian Military Force (ATM) and Ministry of Health and other agencies.

SAR Operation were halt at 10pm due to the rain by Head of Operation from Fire and Rescue Department and continued the next day 17th December at 8am.

Latest update 19/12/2022, entering the fourth day, the search and rescue (SAR) operation for nine remaining victims missing in the landslide tragedy at the Fathers' Organic Farm campsite, Gohtong Jaya, Batang Kali here continues today. Director of the Fire and Rescue Department and Selangor Datuk Norazam Khamis when contacted by Bernama said his side will focus on Sector A (Hillview) and Sector C (Riverside) as well as the surrounding areas that have not been excavated.

field_reports.description:
The flood situation in the three states, namely Kelantan, Terengganu and Perak has worsened due to continuous rain, with more victims evacuated to relief centres. The Malaysian Meteorological Department (MetMalaysia) issued a danger-level weather alert early yesterday, with continuous heavy rain expected to occur across Terengganu and some areas in Kelantan from today until Tuesday. Meanwhile, severe-level continuous heavy rain is expected to occur in several areas in Kedah, Kelantan, Perak and Pahang during the same period, while an alert-level continuous rain notice has been issued for Perlis, Penang, as well as several areas in Kedah, Perak and Johor.

In KELANTAN, the number of flood victims increased to 8,820 people from 2627 families this morning compared to 6,549 people from 1,967 families last night at 10.25 p.m, involving 80 relief centres in seven districts, namely Kota Bharu, Pasir Mas, Tanah Merah, Pasir Puteh, Kuala Krai, Machang and Jeli.

In TERENGGANU, the number of flood-affected residents placed at relief centres increased sharply to 10,111 people from 3,007 families compared to 5,355 people from 1,576 families recorded last night. According to a statement from the State Disaster Management Committee (JPBN) Secretariat, 182 relief centres have been opened in six districts so far. Last two days, the Department of Irrigation and Drainage (JPS) in a statement warned that several areas in the districts of Kuala Terengganu, Besut, Setiu, Hulu Terengganu, Dungun and Kemaman were expected to be flooded from today based on its In flood forecasting model.

In PERAK, a total of 47 victims from 15 families were accommodated in two relief centres as of 2 pm, namely at SM Abdul Rahman Talib in Batu 4 and SK Sungai Tiang Darat. Deputy Prime Minister Datuk Seri Dr Ahmad Zahid Hamidi when met at SK Sungai Tiang Darat said pumps would be built and installed in nine locations in the Bagan Datuk district immediately as suggested by the District Disaster Committee to resolve the flood problem. A flood victim at the relief centre who declined to be identified said that she hoped to be able to return home after having to spend several nights there with her children.

Meanwhile, in JOHOR, the number of flood victims in Segamat remains at 75 from 21 families placed in three relief centres, namely the Kampung Batu Badak Community Hall housing 34 people; Kampung Kuala Paya Community Hall (27) and Kampung Tasek Community Hall (14). The state’s JPBN said that all the victims were from Kampung Seberang Batu Badak, Kampung Batu 5 and Kampung Kuala Paya. It added that river water at Sungai Muar (Buloh Kasap) in Segamat was at the warning level with a height of 8.91m while the weather was reported to be cloudy in several districts, including Pontian, Segamat and Batu Pahat, while it would rain in Johor Bahru and Kota Tinggi this evening.

All the MRCS staff and volunteers in the flood-affected states and districts are still unable to carry out a needs assessment to identify the forms of help and support needed, this is because the staff and volunteers are also stranded, and it is difficult to move due to the flood water level which prevents them from carrying out their tasks. MRCS NHQ will hold an emergency meeting together with the IFRC Malaysia team early today for the purpose of coordinating the response to support the affected states.

Today in one of the official press conference, Deputy Prime Minister Datuk Seri Ahmad Zahid Hamidi explained that the important of relocation of residents must be done before a flood occurs in an area to avoid any difficulties or incidents. The number of flood victims in Johor increased this morning while in Kelantan, Terengganu, Pahang and Perak each remained the same.


The Johor State Disaster Management Committee (JPBN) in a statement announced that Mersing became the latest flood-affected district in the state, making the number of victims increase to 178 people as of 8 this morning compared to 159 last night.


The Director of the Terengganu Fire and Rescue Department, Md Hilman Abd Rashid, also in seperate media interviewed in Terengganu,  insisted that the last-minute evacuation could lead to various risks such as being trapped or stranded if there was a sudden rise in the water level, therefor residents in low-lying areas and at risk of flooding are urged to evacuate early to prevent unwanted incidents from happening

 

Current flood statistic in Malaysia as follows:

  1. Terengganu - 37 people (10 families), 1 temporary relief centre currently operating
  2. Pahang -  142 people (36 families), 1 temporary relief centre operating
  3. Kelantan - 2,019 people (637 families), 7 temporary relief centres operating
  4. Perak - 95 (22 families), 2 temporary relief centres currently operating
  5. Johor -  91 people (24 familis), 4 temporary relief centres currently operating

field_reports.description:
Latest info and alert

A very high and continuous rainfall is expected to occur this midnight (14 December 2022) around the East Coast of the country and according to Meteorologist at the National Antarctic Research Center, Professor Datuk Dr Azizan Abu Samah, based on the forecast from the Global Nullschool.Net model, monsoon rains that produce strong winds in the South China Sea in addition to the La Nina phenomenon and the negative Indian Ocean Dipole (IOD) cause an increase in the number heavy rains and floods on the East Coast.

The Department of Meteorology Malaysia (MetMalaysia) also has issued a warning of continuous heavy rain of severe levels expected to occur in Pahang and Johor until 12 midnight of 14th December 2022 and according to the official statement today informed by MetMalaysia, the heavy rain will occur in district of Pekan and Rompin, Pahang and Mersing, Johor. A continuous (bad) rain warning is issued when there are indications that continuous heavy rain is expected to occur with the amount of rain exceeding 60 millimeters (mm) within six hours  according to the statement.

MetMalaysia also issued a warning of continuous rain level (warning) expected to occur in Pahang involving Kuantan and Bera, while in Johor covering Segamat, Kluang and Kota Tinggi until 12 midnight 14 December 2022.

Meanwhile in Terengganu, The floods has recovered today (Wednesday 14th) with the last 64 victims were allowed to return to their homes. Two Temporary Transfer Centers (PPS) at Sekolah Kebangsaan Atas Tol and Balai Raya Kampung Pantai, Besut were also closed at noon today

field_reports.description:
Flood situation until 2300 13 December 2022

As of 8pm on 13 December 2022 yesterday,  the number of flood victims in Pahang and Terengganu recorded a downward trend while the number of victims increased slightly in Kelantan and Perak .

In Pahang, the number of flood victims decreased yesterday night which was 435 victims compared to 449 people last evening, reported the Pahang State Disaster Management Committee Secretariat, however the water level of Sungai Triang in Bera is still at danger level while five other rivers are at warning level, namely Sungai Jempol and Sungai Pahang in Lubuk Paku which is both in Maran; Pahang River in Paloh Hinai, Pekan; Sungai Belat, Kuantan and Sungai Keratong in Rompin.

The Terengganu JPBN Secretariat, in a statement in yesterday evening, informed that as of 9 o'clock as many as three PPS in three districts are still operating, namely in Kuala Terengganu involving 66 victims; Besut (12) and Setiu (two) while the last PPS in Kemaman (Balai Raya Padang Kemunting) and Dungun (SK Tok Kah) were closed this afternoon. The number of flood victims continued to decrease to 80 people from 24 families compared to 103 people from 28 families last evening.

In Kelantan State, a total of 2,018 flood victims from 635 families in Pasir Mas were accommodated in seven PPS , a slight increase compared to 1,997 victims from 626 families last evening. The Kelantan NADMA Secretariat informed that a total of 712 victims took shelter in SK Tok Deh, SK Kedai Tanjong (47), SK Gual Periok (544), Mukim Padang Licin Mosque (73), PPS Putat Tujoh (157), SK Kubang Kual (251) and SK Sri Kiambang (234)

In Perak, a total of 154 victims from 40 families are still staying in four PPS until 8pm last night, thus recording an increase compared to 143 people

Meanwhile in Johor, the number of flood victims remains at 51 with Segamat being the only district affected by the disaster. According to the District Disaster Management Committee (JPBD), as many as 15 families are still staying in two PPS in the district, involving Kampung Batu Badak Town Hall and Kampung Kuala Paya Town Hall. According to the Malaysian Meteorological Department (MetMalaysia) as of 6.55 yesterday (13 December 2022), a heavy rain and thunderstorm warning was issued for the districts of Johor Bahru, Mersing, Kulai and Kota Tinggi.

Weather Warning
Meteorological Department of Malaysia (MetMalaysia) has issued their latest Continuous Rain Warning (Bad Weather) A Continued Rain Warning (Bad Weather) which will taking effect on December 14, 2022 involving the following areas:

i) Pahang (Town and Rompin); and

ii) Johor (Mersing).

 

Persistent Rain Warning (Weather Alert) comes into effect on December 14, 2022 involving the following areas:

i) Pahang (Kuantan and Bera); and

ii) Johor (Segamat, Kluang and Kota Tinggi)
